title: Feature request: _.hasValue
body:
```
_.hasValue(undefined) --> false
_.hasValue(null) --> false
_.hasValue('') --> false
_.hasValue(0) --> true
_.hasValue(false) --> true
_.hasValue([]) --> false
_.hasValue([undefined, null]) --> false
_.hasValue({}) --> false
_.hasValue({a: undefined, b: {c: null, d: null}}) --> false
_.hasValue(<something>) --> true
```

title: Insufficient validation in Array methods
body:
Most of Array methods in doesn't check if arguments is really arrays.

For example `_.indexOf({length: 9007199254740991}, 'test')` will make node.js stuck.

I believe it could lead to possibility of DoS attack. An attacker with tiny payload could consume a lot of CPU.

title: The way Lodash gets modularized
body:
Hi folks, need advice, I am trying to start thinking about how to split Lodash extension lib to allow 'cherry picking'.

Now I just export a function, which expects a Lodash instance(=global _ by default) as an argument, patches it with several methods using _.mixin and returns it back.

Can I expect, that splitting monolithic lib into separate modules per function will be enough to allow tree shaking? Or I need to consider something else?

My lib now depends on Lodash (full). 

So if I want to get modularized - I should remove lodash dependency and use separately imported methods I only need?

In my entry script, I will just import all the methods and do patching of the Lodash instance, while each method will be still importable separately. 
Is that all I need to care about?

babel-plugin-lodash doesn't support _.chain, and I don't see it in the master, is it going to be dropped? I probably should avoid chaining in my lib too?

What will babel-plugin-lodash do if it will see a call for the method not existed int the Lodash?
Leave this line untouched or it will try to import such method blindly?
Any way to extend babel-plugin-lodash, to make it handle side mixins?

Now my lib is es5 compatible (I hope) is there a way to keep it so, but still use es6 modules? Maybe make an es5 build with Rollup?

Should I care about individual NPM modules per method?
I see an attempt to do so for Lodash, but now it looks like not very maintained...

title: Add optional resolveEmpty parameter to defaultTo

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This is an enhancement to Lodash that extends `defaultTo` with an optional `resolveEmpty` parameter. If supplied, `resolveEmpty` will be used to determine whether the passed `value` is empty and that `defaultValue` should be returned.

This would allow the following usage examples, amongst many others:

1. Default to a value when given a value considered empty by `lodash.isEmpty`:

```js
defaultTo('', defaultValue, isEmpty);
```

2. Default to a value after running `lodash.attempt` on a statement that may return an error using `lodash.isError`.

```js
defaultTo(attempt(require, filePath), defaultValue, isError);
```

title: _.round(Infinity, 2) returns NaN
body:
```
_.round(Infinity) // Infinity
_.round(Infinity, 2) // NaN
```
Logically, it doesn't makes sense to round Infinity and especially round it to 2 decimal places. However, this is not a contrived example. The value being passed into _.round() is often a finite number where I need to round to 2 decimal places. Occasionally, the value is Infinity, which is a valid value in my case and should return Infinity. However, it returns NaN. 

I can put guards in my code to not round if the incoming value is Infinity, but 
a) It's not ideal
b) There is the inconsistency with `_.round(Infinity)` which works as I would expect

Is this an error or an edge case that needs to be guarded against? Thanks

title: OrderBy not working as expected

Proposal: _.while
Update README.md / Added collection with Bit
body:
Shared Lodash with Bit (https://github.com/teambit/bit) so now there's a component collection for the library (https://bit.dev/lodash/lodash) - took about 10 minutes :).

There are several added benefits for this:
1. People can now visually explore the collection and play with each function online (example: https://bit.dev/lodash/lodash/is-match)
2. They can install each function as a package with NPM and Yarn (I know you already did that by refactoring, publishing each package etc)
3. People can use Bit to develop each component right from their own project and best fit it to their needs.

I think this adds to the engaging modular expirience of people working with Lodash. I'd be very happy to hand over ownership over the organization + components and help update it if you like. I hope you find it useful!

title: Elect / Nominate representative(s) to the OpenJS Foundation CPC
body:
## Context
As part of the new [OpenJS Foundation's bylaws](https://github.com/openjs-foundation/bootstrap/blob/master/artifacts/OpenJS-Foundation-Initial-Merged-Bylaws.pdf), the Cross Project Council (CPC) has been [chartered](https://github.com/openjs-foundation/bootstrap/tree/master/proposals/stage-2/CPC_CHARTER) to serve as the primary governing body for programs and regular support of Foundation projects. For example, it will be responsible for things like infrastructure, travel assistance, CoC support, accepting new projects into the foundation, and mentorship programs to name a few. It will also be responsible for electing board representative(s) to the OpenJS Foundation board of directors.

**Any interested person from our project communities can attend CPC meetings and volunteer to participate in tasks.** For most programs, the CPC is expected to operate on the consensus of OpenJS Foundation project members. Issues that require a vote - namely the election of Board representatives and accepting a new project - will be memorialized by a voting CPC membership comprised of up to 2 representatives from Impact level projects and 2 representatives from Growth and At-Large stages.

If you'd like more info/context on the governance of the OpenJS Foundation, please let me know or follow this repo. The main point I hope you take away is that the foundation is to be run by and for the projects, and to do that we need participants from the project community.

## Request
As an At Large stage project, Lodash is encouraged to send representatives to participate in CPC meetings, to advise on programs and support that will be helpful to it, and to nominate someone from the project community to serve in a voting capacity. 

We anticipate having our first 'official' CPC meeting on May 30 or 31 at the Collaborator Summit in Berlin (sidebar, you should come!). In the interim, we would love for project members to participate in the Bootstrap CPC meetings which are currently held on Mondays (watch [this repo](https://github.com/openjs-foundation/bootstrap/issues/150) for meeting details).

If this is not the correct forum to raise this, please let me know and I will close the issue and post it in the preferred channel. Note that I'm posting essentially the same message to all OpenJS Foundation project repos, because I want to get the word out and make sure we all have the same information. 

your pal,
Jory

title: escape and lodash.escape differ in escaping backticks
body:
Hi there, I had been using the full lodash library in an app, and realized I only need a few functions, so switched out for lodash.* npm modules. When I installed lodash.escape separately, I noticed some different behavior. Namely, lodash.escape _escapes_ backticks, while lodash's escape does not... unless I'm missing something? Here's the versions I'm using and some example output:

"lodash": "^4.17.11",
"lodash.escape": "^4.0.1",

```
import { escape } from 'lodash';

let str = escape('a `Messaging.EmailFileAttachment` array');
console.log(str); // 'a `Messaging.EmailFileAttachment` array'
```
vs.
```
import escape from 'lodash.escape';

let str = escape('a `Messaging.EmailFileAttachment` array');
console.log(str); // 'a `Messaging.EmailFileAttachment` array'
```

title: _.get: clarification on handling of string path vs array path
body:
Currently, when passing an array to `_.get`, each element in the array must be one level deeper in the object. I expected that I could compose any paths in the array and `_.get` would be able to resolve each path segment in the array. Below is an example of what I mean. 

```js
const obj = { foo: { bar: [{ baz: 1 }, { baz: 2 }, { baz: 3 }] } }

_.get(obj, 'foo.bar[1].baz') // returns 2
_.get(obj, ['foo', 'bar', '1', 'baz']) // returns 2
_.get(obj, ['foo.bar[1]', 'baz']) // returns undefined
```

This may be intended, but it seems like something that could be supported.

title: Documentation: [Function iteratee=_.identity] could be String too
body:
A lot of functions we can argument the `iteratee` parameter with a String, but the doc specifics that it allows only `Function`. I think that the best typehint for it is `{Function|String}`.

```js
    /**
     * @see https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.11/lodash.js#L9237-L9260
     * @param {Array|Object} collection The collection to iterate over.
     * @param {Function} [iteratee=_.identity] The function invoked per iteration.
     */
    function flatMap(collection, iteratee) { ... }
```

title: Is the number of callback arguments a safe criteria for optimization?
body:
Hi there, need advice, please.

Imagine some iteration method, which passes some data as arguments into the given callback:

_.eachDeep(obj, (value,key,parent,context)=>{});

How do you think, will it be safe enough inside eachDeep to rely on the number of arguments actually expected by given callback ( [callback.length](https://developer.mozilla.org/ru/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function/length) ) when deciding to omit the last argument and improve performance/resources consumption this way?

`context` is a complex object and extra computations/memory needed to build it. 

So if callback doesn't expect the fourth argument explicitly, there are low chances developer is going to use `arguments` or `rest` parameter to get it anyway.
Am I right? 
I just don't want to make developer specify additional option to turn building `context` on/off manually. Callback declaration is speaking enough in this case.
Is it good practice? 
Did you ever consider such a possibility in some Lodash methods?

title: Proposal: findIndex and findLastIndex additional parameter
body:
Hi,

It will be nice that findIndex and findLastIndex to have an optional additional index parameter `i`. There could be multiple elements matching the given predicate and the method could return the `i`th element matching that predicate. The default value should be 1.

title: Please add support for mathematical intervals within collection paths for get and set methods
mergeWith: stack passed to customizer should always be defined
body:
Summary:
If the first values encountered in the `object` in mergeWith are not objects, `stack` is undefined when passed to the `customizer`. Once the first object-ish value is encountered, `stack` gets initialized, and all further calls to `customizer` include a defined `stack`. This PR makes `stack` always defined, even before the first object-ish value is encountered.

title: mergeWith: stack passed to customizer should always be defined
body:
Summary:
If the first values encountered in the `object` in mergeWith are not objects, `stack` is undefined when passed to the `customizer`. Once the first object-ish value is encountered, `stack` gets initialized, and all further calls to `customizer` include a defined `stack`. This PR makes `stack` always defined, even before the first object-ish value is encountered.

title: Please improve and add ES6 import instructions for lodash and per package modules
body:
I was just trying to use [lodash.camelcase](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash.camelcase) but was unclear how to `import` it.

Always trips me up

```ts
import * as camelcase from "lodash.camelcase";
import * as capitalize from "lodash.capitalize";
```

Normally I find that `*` is used to return an Object where each key is an API method.

`require` is "so ~2010-2015"

I would suggest you keep this for backwards compatibility but also export individual const names and perhaps a default export as well

I now see there is a [lodash-es](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash-es) but was too clear from the docs.

title: sampleSize doesn't need to exist
body:
In my opinion, a cleaner API would be a single sample function with an optional size parameter.

`sampleSize`'s size parameter is already somewhat optional. I can give it null and it will set it to `1`, but only with `n == null`
If I send a random other non-number value which`n  != null ` it will just return an empty array, effectively failing silently.

I propose a positive > 0 number check on the parameter instead. Preferably even throwing an error but I don't think anything in lodash does that yet.

title: Fix _.maxBy and _.minBy
the precision of createRound
body:
Hello!
I have a question about `.internal.createRound`.
In the https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/4085 commit, I think the implementing is not correct. In JavaScript, the `Number.MAX_VALUE` is `1.7976931348623157e+308`, the `Number.MIN_VALUE` is `5e-324`. So I think the maximum exponential should be `+308`, and the minimum exponential should be `-324`. There are some problems about _.ceil():
```js
_.ceil(Number.MIN_VALUE, 294) 
// expect 1e-294, but return 1e-292

_.ceil(1.123e+308,-307) 
// expect 1.2e+308, but return 1.123e+308
```

title: debounce maxWait undefined option has not the same behavior as not passing the option
body:
The behavior of debounce is not the same, if I pass a undefined maxWait option instead of not passing this option.
Because this option is a numeric property, the behavior should be the same if the option value is undefined or the option is not present. Otherwise the function caller needs to check if the maxWait value is undefined and in that case not pass the option to the debounce function.

With a undefined maxWait, the function gets called after the wait time:
```
const debounceOpts = {maxWait: undefined };
debounce(() => {console.log('maxWait undefined', 1000, debounceOpts});
```

This works as expected:
`debounce(() => {console.log('no debounceOpts', 1000});`

title: Group By limits returning objects
a question about the function assignMergeValue
body:
i am reading the source code of lodash, when i see the function assignMergeValue;
````
import baseAssignValue from './baseAssignValue.js'
import eq from '../eq.js'

/**
 * This function is like `assignValue` except that it doesn't assign
 * `undefined` values.
 *
 * @private
 * @param {Object} object The object to modify.
 * @param {string} key The key of the property to assign.
 * @param {*} value The value to assign.
 */
function assignMergeValue(object, key, value) {
  if ((value !== undefined && !eq(object[key], value)) ||
      (value === undefined && !(key in object))) {
    baseAssignValue(object, key, value)
  }
}

export default assignMergeValue
````
which makes me wonder is this condition:
````
(value !== undefined && !eq(object[key], value)) ||  (value === undefined && !(key in object))
````

the second condition is `value === undefined`, and the `key` is in the specified object or object's prototype chain, why not use `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty`?  in operator will find the  `key` in object or its prototype chain。

i hope it's just my error. hope someone tell me why?

title: orderBy not working?
body:
This is the example straight out of the docs:
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.11#orderBy

```
var users = [
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 48 },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 34 },
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 40 },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 36 }
];
_.orderBy(users, ['user', 'age'], ['asc', 'desc']);
// => objects for [['barney', 36], ['barney', 34], ['fred', 48], ['fred', 40]]
console.dir(users);
```
outputs: (didn't seem to do any sorting)
```
[ { user: 'fred', age: 48 },
  { user: 'barney', age: 34 },
  { user: 'fred', age: 40 },
  { user: 'barney', age: 36 } ]

```

node.js
am I missing something?

title: Unexpected _.startCase spacing of numbers
clarify _.clone behavior
body:
Mainly behavior around cloning/copying prototypes.

The [docs say](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/clone.js) that `_.clone` uses ["structured clone algorithm"](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Structured_clone_algorithm), where MDN links to a w3c spec where it states it's been deprecated:

> This specification used to define a "structured clone" algorithm, and more recently a StructuredClone abstract operation. However, in practice all known uses of it were better served by separate serialization and deserialization steps, so it was removed.

Not sure if lodash then follows the [StructuredSerializeInternal](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/infrastructure.html#section-structuredserializeinternal) algo, or the previous spec which is nowhere to be found now.

Either way, I couldn't find what's the supposed behavior around cloning object's prototype.

From source/behavior, it's obvious `_.clone` sets the cloned object's prototype to the original object's prototype, but it'd be nice to document it.

MDN states:

> The prototype chain does not get walked and duplicated.

Which isn't super clear whether the prototype should be copied at all.

title: groupBy() don't always preserve the order of array collection
body:
groupBy() documentation says: The order of grouped values is determined by the order they occur in collection. 

But if you have a list like this, where you have a number in the "name" property:

```
var list = [
  { 'name': 'a' },
  { 'name': 'b' },
  { 'name': 'b' },
  { 'name': 'a' },
  { 'name': '1' },
];
```
groupBy("name") it will always returned this "number group" as a first one.


here is a [jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/acaktas/wj8e5p1n/7/)

title: _.result returns default value when property is null
`_.word()` does not support `pattern` as a String
body:
The docs state that `pattern` can be a String, but since it's passed directly to `string.match()`, it can only result in errors or non-global regexes.

```javascript
_.words('foo bar', 'foo')
// ["foo", index: 0, input: "foo bar", groups: undefined]

_.words('foo bar', '[')
// Error
```

title: Add `pattern` parameter to case methods
body:
I'm proposing adding an optional second parameter `pattern` to case methods, which would be passed to the underlying `_.words` function.

```javascript
_.kebabCase('eg1: 100s of 3D OMGs in the \'90s', /[a-zA-Z0-9]+/g)
// eg1-100s-of-3d-omgs-in-the-90s
```

Could remedy questions like #4141

title: _.get behavior with empty array as path?
body:
```javascript
// Current behavior
_.get(x, []); // returns undefined

// Expected behavior
_.get(x, []); // returns x
```

I understand that string paths have inherent ambiguity, so it makes sense why `_.get(x, "")` may retrieve `x[""]`

However, array-based paths are unambiguous. There is only one possible traversal for any given path. It seems that behavior would be more consistent if `_.get(x, [])` returned `x`. It would look like:

```javascript
_.get(x, ["a", "b"]); // returns x["a"]["b"]
_.get(x, ["a"]); // returns x["a"]
_.get(x, []); // returns x
```

Is there a reason it returns `undefined` instead?

title: Adding pickTruthyValues function to lodash library
body:
# Description

This function will take an object and remove any empty/falsy values from it. It will also do a deep search of nested objects and arrays.

title: differenceBy and differenceWith return an unexpected result for an edge case
body:
Version used: `4.17.11`

Steps to reproduce:
```js
const values = [{ a: 'x', b: 2 }, { a: 'y', b: 2 }]
const oldValues = [{ a: 'x', b: 2 }, { a: 'y', b: 1 }]

differenceBy(values, olValues, 'b') // => []; Expected: { a: 'y', b: 2 }

// However, changing the order of values works
differenceBy(oldValues, values, 'b') // => { a: 'y', b: 1 }
```

After looking into the implementation of the [baseDifference](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/baseDifference.js#L21) function I realized that there is a chance this issue might not qualify as a bug. The algorithm loops through each element of the first array and compares its [computed value](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/baseDifference.js#L44) to all the [flattened](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/differenceBy.js#L32) values of the second array. Since it finds a corresponding value, it continues with the outer loop effectively moving onto the next element of the array (`values`) and not pushing the expected difference to the result set.

Would anyone expect the same result as me or is this just not the real intention of the implemented difference functions?

title: Merging an object with an array creates an object with all array functions
body:
After bumping from version `2.4.2` to `4.17.11` There is a weird behaviour when running 
`_.merge({}, [])`. In `2.4.2` it resulted in an empty object `{}` while in `4.17.11` I'm getting an object that contains all the function of the array:
```
{
    all: ...,
    any: ...,
    clear: ...,
    clone: ...,
    collect: ...,
    ...
}
```

title: Sum gives wrong result with decimal values
Motivation behind predicate signature
body:
HI, I need an advise related to predicate signature.

In most cases the predicate is invoked with three arguments: value, index|key, collection.

I've never used third argument in practice, but I can imagine it can be useful for example to make some decision relying on sibling element's data. 
For example we can check if collection[index+1].flag === true and then return something from predicate accordingly.

I want to refactor predicate signature in the Deepdash extension, to make it conform Lodash.
Now predicate in eachDeep/filterDeep looks like this:
`(value, key|index, path, depth, parentValue, parentKey, parentPath, fullParentsStack(optional))=>{}`

As you see there is no `collection` so I want to add it.

In terms of deep walking, to gain something useful from `collection` we need full current `path`, not only `key|index`
So I want to pass into predicate `value, key|index, path` and `collection` arguments

Rest of the arguments are pretty useful too, so I'll pack them into last object argument `context`

So finally deep version of predicate should be like this:
`(value, key|index,path,collection,context={parentValue, parentKey,parentPath, parents,depth})`

My question is about most rational order of arguments.

Does it make sense to strictly follow Lodash version in first three args:
`value,key,collection,    path,context`
will it have some compatibility benefits in case of mixed Lodash/Deepdash usage? 
In this case predicates has almost identical signatures both for Lodash and Deepdash

Or I'll better choose more intuitive order
`value, key,path,collection,   context`?
because having identical with Lodash signatures has no practical appliance?

title: .uniqWith skipping 1 comparison
why { } required for single statement assignment with _.forEach
body:
If I need to do assignment of the value to one property and I need to do it for collection of the object I used _.forEach 

`_.forEach( tabs, t => t.active = false );`  [not working fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/stdeepak22/47nuscot/32)

Above doesn't work well, while if I use curly braces { } around arrow function it works well. 

`_.forEach( tabs, t => { t.active = false } );`  [working fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/stdeepak22/47nuscot/34)


I have provided both- working/non working fiddle.
Just **click on Tab1,2,3 buttons multiple times to reproduce it.**

title: Orderby not working with custom sort function
Cancel old timer, editing pr #4139
body:
Update PR: [#4139](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/4139)

### Comments
I thought `setTimeout` basically also needs `clearTimeout` to clear its older time identifier, but according to this document, `setTimeout` does not seem to need to clear its timer.

> _6.1.2.4 Processing model_
> An event loop must continually run through the following steps for as long as it exists.
> ...
> 3. Remove that task from its task queue.

`requestAnimationFrame`, however, seems to need to clear the timer, using `cancelAnimationFrame` by the reason below.

> The cancelAnimationFrame(_handle_) method must run the following steps:
> ...
> 3. Remove callbacks[_handle_].

### References
[6.1.4.2 Processing model - event loop](https://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-html5-20110525/webappapis.html#event-loop)
[Animation frames](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/imagebitmap-and-animations.html#animation-frames)

### Conclusion
But, to answer the question you asked in issue [#4138](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4138)
> What problems does this create

I do not honestly think that would cause any problems unless you use this codes on dashboard-like application which is supposed to be displayed 24/7 and the task queue of the event loop will end up being overflow. For even small but better performance, I still believe `cancelAnimationFrame` is required.

title: How merge mutil object in array with lodash?
reduce not working as expected with objects
isMap is always false on IE11
body:
version: 4.17.11

From inside the IE 11 console:

```
var m = new Map();
m instanceof Map;   // true
_.isMap(m);   // false
m.toString();  // "[object Object]"  <--- the issue...
```

It appears that IE 11 treats `Map` as an `Object`. `isMap` expects `getTag` to return `"[object Map]"`

title: Maximum call stack size exceeded on lodash.clonedeep / react native 0.57.5
body:
We've had some issues in the past few weeks with react native apps throwing "Maximum call stack size exceeded" crashes on iOS devices.

The issue was difficult to track since simulators would crash only with debugger closed (Crash doesn't occur if debugger on and simulator uses browers' stack).

Crash also occurs on iOS physical devices. Testing revealed the issue is triggered by packages that use lodash.clonedeep and affects (at least starting with) react native  version 0.57.5. We didn't test if this occurs with older versions of RN.

Issue was triggered when we upgraded from RN 0.54/0.55 to latest.

title: _.omit doesn't work when passed a Set of paths
body:
`_.omit({foo: 1}, new Set(['foo']))` returns `{foo: 1}`, when I would expect it to return an empty object.

`_.omit({foo: 1}, ['foo'])` and `_.omit({foo: 1}, ...new Set(['foo']))` both return empty objects as expected.

I entered these statements in my browser console on https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.11 in Chrome.

title: Add initial test files from lodash v4.
body:
These files were created using a simplistic AST manipulator using `recast` to preserve formatting. There's bound to be a huge chunk of errors, but this serves as a good start. QUnit was replaced with Mocha, with ES2015 imports running via `esm`.

As far as possible, QUnit-specific syntax has been replaced with Mocha's `describe` and `it`, while the native Node.js `assert` module is used for assertions. Files in the `test` directory ending in `.test.js` will be treated as test files.

I've included all tests, including those for methods removed in the upcoming v5, for posterity's sake. Feel free to cherry-pick only relevant files. Functions to be tested are imported unless they were run using computed `lodash[fn]` style syntax, in which case they require updating. The files also conform to the old code style, which is drastically different from the current semicolon-free, ES2015-friendly code, so maybe a run of prettier/eslint/jscodeshift/*insert popular code formatter here* could help in the cleanup. Also, loads of legacy constructs like `isNpm` and `isModularize` can slowly be removed when porting

title: isEqual returns inconsistent results with cyclic objects
OrderBy: When using orderby desc, nulls are placed at the front of the array
Use the merge method to get two different results
body:
What causes the following two cases to get different results? 
```js
// case #1:
var target = [ {m1: console.log}, {m1: console.log}, {m1: console.log} ]
var source = [ { a: 1, b: 2 }, { a: 2, b: 3 }, { a: 3, b: 4 }] 
_.merge(target, source)

// case #2:
var target = Array(3).fill({ m1:  console.log})
var source = [ { a: 1, b: 2 }, { a: 2, b: 3 }, { a: 3, b: 4 }] 
_.merge(target, source)

```

Below is result that I got
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24240963/51727857-e8923000-20a8-11e9-8e97-5c3ec6bc8ab9.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24240963/51727867-f5168880-20a8-11e9-8f49-f05fd1db4d0c.png)


Is this a logical error in the merge method, or is it because I am trapped ?
